title: A Sincere question for the Reds
body:
All these Ideas, opinions, suggestions about gameplay overall do they matter, at all? 

I am really curious about how Rito handle this informations, I mean do you want us to shut up and be grateful for what we have or do you really want us to express our opinions and see changes based on this very opinions.

I do understand that RIOT Team of developers and managers have their agenda and probably understand more of their game, than we do. But I can't help to think there's value on community suggestions. Can I get a Red to explain how this matter is handle on the HQ? I really want to know.



Thank you for your time, I will try to ignore Toxic behavior and will only acknowledge Red's reply or serious replies. 



PS: We need more flat MS items without AS, and with other bruiser stats. Try new Phage upgrade branches.

replies.body:
So I'm going to speaking mostly from personal experience on how I use the forums and other forms of community feedback, as different rioters use community feedback differently. If I had to broadly categorize I would say I use community feedback in 5 ways.

*Feeling out General Sentiment* - This is pretty broad but this is when I search for general trends, issues, and feedback. This is generally for broad answering questions like
"What are people most interested or vocal about?"
"Aside from the concrete data - do people feel that this character is OP or UP?"
"What elements of a larger patch or feature are people most drawn to or that is most contentious"

*Easy Wins* - These are specific changes that are really easy to do, something I could tackle over lunch without sacrificing my current projects. Often these are champion QoL fixes or bug/feel investigations.
Examples include
Switching a skill to a new targeting indicator
Investigating reports of a characters AA feeling weird
Updates to a champions recommended items
Minor particle updates I can fix with my bad art skills (ex- displaying all 3 cards during Twisted Fates Pick a Card for colorblind people)

*Discovering Important or unImportant elements *- When I was working on the Udyr and Trundle updates a long time ago reading community feedback on those champions in general was super useful in evaluating what elements of the character people seemed most attached with on each character and what they simply didn't care about. I found out pretty quickly, and not super surprisingly, that people didn't really care about the flat bonus AP on phoenix stance and it was viewed as practically worthless. Stripping this bonus damage out allowed me to put the phoenix fire breath cone on the very first punch upon switching stances for nearly identical total damage but made him more satisfying and allowed him more interesting positional play and let him rotate stances faster.

*Discussion Topics on Contentious Issues *- Seeing people propose specific solutions for issues and the response to those solutions is really valuable. A specific example here would be the Critical Strike or Grievous Wounds discussions that pop up from time to time. Even if the issues discussed aren't ones we are working on right this minute the discussions are still valuable to have so we can make progress faster on them when we start working on changes.

*Specific Solutions *- When I'm stuck on something as a dev it can be helpful to get specific suggestions. When I worked on the mastery tree updates for the previous seasons (we didn't do one this time around). Stuff like focusing on laning power for early 9pt masteries, fusing options that didn't need to be separate (such as phys and mag pen or the improved Summoner Spell options), pickpocket variant for melee champs etc, came from community feedback delivered once each version went out and was incorporated into the next iteration.

Anyways that's a really long way of saying, yes I find a lot of value in people posting stuff for a variety of reasons, but it varies greatly based on the projects I'm working on, and how much those issues are discussed. 

I hope this was helpful Wiegraf (I'm assuming your name is a FFT reference btw?).

-Feral {{champion:120}}

So I have a question for you. Out of curiosity, what was the reason for not changing masteries for Season 5?? Too busy with other changes, or just that the masteries are still good for another season or two, or what??

Few reasons, on the value side updating the trees has increasingly less value each time we do it. Not saying there isn't value but it gets more and more into small scale numbers tuning (or in mastery cases REALLY small numbers tuning) and less about solving largescale problem. This isn't terrible surprising as when we approached them initially in Season 2 it was a pretty substantial overhaul, the S3 and S4 updates while certainly improvements were more on the lighter tuning side of things. 

In addition, the cost of doing this adjustment is really high. We need to wipe all players mastery pages each time we do an update beyond a very simple balancing change which based on a lot of player feedback is something people don't want to go through unless there are really substantial gains. 

With so much focus on the jungle this preseason having a characters baseline statistics stable was really beneficial for getting the strength and tuning of the jungle where we wanted it to be. Runes and masteries have such a huge impact on that system keeping as many variables steady as we could is highly beneficial. 

With those factors in mind and the ever increasing long list of other stuff we wanted to get done it didn't make sense to spend a lot of time this preseason focusing on the mastery system.

TL:DR - High cost, low gains, messes with jangle jangle, other stuff we want to do.

> TL:DR - High cost, low gains, messes with jangle jangle, other stuff we want to do. 


Have you ever considered making Masteries a little more EXCITING than *"get 36 health"*?


For instance, more cool stuff like Spellblade which gives you an on-hit effect. More of that mastery that lets supports gain passive gold when ally CS's.

Less* "gain arbritrary number of free stats"*


Maybe have more masteries provide stuff you can't get out of common items?

That's definitely something we'd like to do and overall a noble goal. It's why the trend over the years with masteries has been to shift more into unique effects. There is an increasing complexity cost if you go too hard on this mentality where you have 30 unique effects all interacting simultaneously and unless there is substantial power creep accompanying these effects most of these will be unnoticeable invisible. For these to ultimately be both more interesting mechanically and noticeable we'd probably have to cut down the number of masteries chosen down from 30 but that would require a larger rework that we'd have to do at a later time.

Sounds promising.

At the end of the day, I think Masteries should feel less like just another set of rune page stuck into your champion.
This would be very interesting, kinda like a "talen tree" wher you unlock unique effect that you can tailor around your favourite champs ^^

So in other words, singular underwhelming masteries, like say Runic Blessing just for example, can be improved on without doing complete wipes of every players' pages.  I recall you already did this before near the beginning of the season when Perseverance's overwhelming strength was cut in half.
Correct.
Why have the masteries that grant health and mana regen not chaged with the other health and mana changes in preseason?

I feel that there could be some moving around of some of the masteries in the trees and some tweaks (such as the melee forbidden Bandit mastery, God its so bad for melee) 

I completely understand the low gain high cost aspect of it as there is only so much one is allowed to have on the masteries without breaking the game again, due to newer champions (can't have crit chance in masteries because YASUO.) Though with NO changes happening to runes (statwise) and masteries we will see the same champions constantly and the only change that took place this preseason is the Jungle changes. It feels rather lackluster in comparison to last preseason where a lot of the core gameplay was changed and it broadened the number of champions played exponentially. Then there is th works that were supposed to be done in season 4 but were not touched on (fighter rework, improved communication with the community (force us on boards yet most reds use only reddit), etc) 


There is also fundamental game aspects I believe should be looked into but thats another topic.

Thank you! 

I guess you made my day sir. Is good to know it matters somehow.

Yes it is and FFT needs a sequel btw..

Agreed, you should get the license and the funding to make that happen! 

P.S. - if you can make that happen and need design help - call me :)

It's getting something of a spiritual successor, I think:
[Unsung Story](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/482445197/unsung-story-tale-of-the-guardians)
Wow.. :D Thanks man.. Hope is good tho

Correct. I work primarily on gameplay.

May I ask where or how the playerbase could get some communication going on Game design topics? 

I ask because there is usually no red posts so it feels as if we are just talking to ourselves?

Depends on the topic and varying level of availability of design bros but I've worked on the majority of the design groups at some point. Do you have any question in particular or a is it mostly a request for more red interaction overall from design dudes?

Mainly more interactions on topics, but There are a few topics in particular that I wish would be addressed. Mainly the talks about tanks being useless, Melees being completely destroyed overall(see KALISTA passive and ranged overall dominance), the Idea of Crit being 150% from 200% (so not all adcs have to be made around the requirement of IE thus casters can come back),  and Summoner spells rework (see 97.6% flash use in the last two seasons and almost 0% use of clairvoyance, cleanse, revive.)

these are some of the ideas that I found need to atleast be looked at and talked about (here as in the boards not reddit so WE can see it on the OFFICIAL LoL website)

Many of those topics have been discussed several times before, if you go through the red tracker you will find topics about ranged dominance and ranged being useless, probably 20-30 topics about summoner spell dominance, there is a few topics about crits as well.

Those are topics that tend to come up over and over, not to say they are not interesting, I'd love to have more discussions about crit personally. A note though, is to avoid starting discussion so skewed "tanks being useless", "melees being completely destroyed" a it is exaggerations.  It sets a negative tone for the whole topic, and skews discussion, it's better to start neutral and instead let the argument talk for themself setting the tone.

There have been times when opposite are true, and it's a reason things are as they are, and generally it goes back to fun.
They haven't figured out a FUN way to make melees work, only autos and melees are a bit too simplistic and boring. There is less skill expression for a melee as the positional requirement and spacing is not there to same extent, and this is a core issue that need to be solved. Same issues with tanks and bruisers, when those classes are dominating the game tend to be not very fun, as their core gameplay is not overly exciting alone, but BECOMES exciting when in a ranged dominating environment, since timing becomes much more crucial then, and then you are required to abuse the mistakes ranged makes.

Same thing with summoner spells, variety for sake of variety is useless, and that is the reason flash is so overused. It's a versatile spell, that is fun and allows for skill expression. They have not managed to make nearly as fun other spells, with as much mastery and skill attached to them, it's the reasons a few of the spells lay in the dust. Rewards vs Cost is not high enough, current setup works, and making improvement is difficult, and unless you make a spell as good from a design perspective as flash, then it's not worth it to introduce variety.

So its fun for the player to just be pecked at by someone from range that never has to come near you and just can walk around you and you can do nothing? That's kinda what you just said. Heres the thing is it fun to play against a Kalista, the answer is almost always no as even as a ranged champion she can just get away or chase you down easily and you can do nothing about it. It takes more skill for the melee player to outplay the ranged player than it does the ranged to "outplay" the melee champion. I will agree that when tanks are too strong and can't be killed it does seem boring but when tanks are 4 or 5 shot by the ADC it is not fun to watch, Tanking is hard to make fun as they have almost completely been replace by bruisers. Bruisers were made because there needed to be an inbetween for the Damage dealers and the tank as a secondary source of damage, The problem is that bruisers (typically) can tank the same amount and deal damage at the same time thus tanks are unnecessary. 

Another thing I would like to say about your post is saying its exciting when ranged is dominating the game, this I completely disagree with as the ranged/melee risk reward is completely out of wack. The ranged is allowed to make more mistakes in positioning as they are outside of the Attack range of the opponent so low risk high reward, now the melee can not make a mistake otherwise they are in full retaliation range and are unable to retaliate themselves, one would think high risk high reward no? Wrong it is High risk medium reward as the existence of flash allows the ranged champion a out thus the medium reward, now what most people say back to that is you have flash too so just follow up, This would be true if the melee has a slow of decent % and the ranged can't displace or slow the melee (most do) and even if they don't have soft or hard cc they can still just walk away as they are usually out of range of the melee even after flash despite ranged champions having lower ms base.

> Same thing with summoner spells, variety for sake of variety is useless, and that is the reason flash is so overused. It's a versatile spell, that is fun and allows for skill expression. They have not managed to make nearly as fun other spells, with as much mastery and skill attached to them, it's the reasons a few of the spells lay in the dust. Rewards vs Cost is not high enough, current setup works, and making improvement is difficult, and unless you make a spell as good from a design perspective as flash, then it's not worth it to introduce variety.

Variety for the sake of variety would be useless if there was variety and everything was already balanced. The problem is that the overuse of flash a spell which is dominant not because it is OP but is because it is required by the base design of the spell, it has every thing one needs in one spell, it has too much utility on it. Have a look at ghost, with all the slows in the game now it has little purpose except on a select few champions. 

Flash on the other hand isnt affected by slows, I have preached this before and I even talked to Ghostcrawler who when asked on the topic of Smite being nerfed so it doesn't become too dominant while flash is taken nearly 10 times out of 10 said and I quote "Flash is an exception to that philosophy. We don't mind seeing it a lot or nearly all the time. It's more like Recall." Thus why is it not free? the answer is because there are a select few champions who don't require it (at all times) and I will quote him again "No I don't mind. Making Flash another B is on the table. The issues are not everyone takes Flash and we don't want 2+Flash." 

This is because each spell should be unique and have a niche which it fills. Flash fills multiple niches and is a universally good spell on anyone due to BAD design. It can do its own thing (go over walls) that's a good thing but it can also take the place of other summoner spells as it can be used as a mild alternative to them while having its own niche, Barrier can be replaced somewhat by just using flash and dodging the shot (if a skill shot), Ghost can be replaced somewhat by flash by being a either gap close or escape that is unaffected by slows, same with heal as it can be used to make the distance heal would have given with its MS boost (not the health regain). To fix this the other spells need to be tuned up to compensate, Ghost should either make you immune to slows or while its active reduce all slows effects by 50%, Barrier should grant either increased defenses while active or just be flat damage reduction, Heal doesn't need to be changed as it's heal is equally unique, Clarity needs to grant energy as well as mana and possibly grant % cd reduced on your spells (kinda like Yi's ultimate passive), Teleport, exhaust, smite, and ignite are in a decent place in my opinion, while Cleanse and Clairvoyance need to be looked at really bad as they are taken the least of all the summoner spells since trinkets were introduced.


Sorry if this post is kinda scatter brained, its 7am and I am really sleepy, that and had a rough last few games so i'm kinda irritated.

EDIT: kinda edited to fix some of my scatter brainedness, god i'm tired.

> Yes, most of them many months ago and them just dropping it and nothing coming from it at all this is the problem. It has shown itself in many threads of late that players no longer feel as if anything they say has any meaning. Hell look at this thread, the fact that players feel this way from a company that says they are player driven speaks volumes.

Yes I know this feeling, but it is understandable, because the community is getting very big, there just is too many users and too few devs. And this is just english speaking users, which is in minority compared to non-english communities, like chinese and korean.

> Heres the thing is it fun to play against a Kalista, the answer is almost always no as even as a ranged champion she can just get away or chase you down easily and you can do nothing about it. It takes more skill for the melee player to outplay the ranged player than it does the ranged to "outplay" the melee champion.

Yes, Kalista is obnoxious, I agree, but she is not norm for ranged champs. She is... special. Outplaying a ranged is not easy no, but if you look how the matchups go for trynda, yi, yasuo, it's pretty much get one hit and you are dead. They have overcompensated the lack of engage, with extreme damage, and they have tools to avoid being kited too much, on several of the bruisers, like irelia or jax.

Generally the interaction is not overly exciting, they have not figured out proper tools for EXCITING interactions. Melees get perma-kited, ranged get instant-kill with no chance of comeback, it's hard to tweak it for something inbetween, but right now overall it's somewhere inbetween. Kalista and Ashe are champs that pushes for perma-kiting though.

> This is because each spell should be unique and have a niche which it fills. Flash fills multiple niches and is a universally good spell on anyone due to BAD design.

Yes and no, universal tools are bad design, but flash is universal because of how ingenious it is.

I mean you can easily buff ghost to be better, but it doesn't have nearly as exciting interactions. With ghost you outrun anyone, it's highly binary, and the play potential with it is low, you just run at them and that's it. If you lower the slow effects of it, then sure it works better, but is it making the game more fun?

It means Darius, Olaf and many other champs is much harder to kite, it means the ranged champs would very much be shut out, it would be bruiser heaven. Overall it would shake things up massively, and not really improve game health or fun overly much. It would pretty much be a binary "can't be kited/free escape" button.

This is the reason why it's hard to make new summoner spells, you can ALWAYS buff them to be as strong as flash, and make flash redundant, but are you sure you want to play a game where barrier/exhaust is the norm?

Those first three (Yi, Tryndamere, and Yasuo) are all melee carries so they have to have lots of damage to compensate. While Irelia and Jax are more toward melee carry than bruisers but still have a very bruiser kit. the reason they are overcompensated is the fact of how powerful range is, with a ranged champion one can orb walk and increase your damage extremely, melee's can kind of orb walk though their animation is faster and has no back swing on some champions.


> Generally the interaction is not overly exciting, they have not figured out proper tools for EXCITING interactions. Melees get perma-kited, ranged get instant-kill with no chance of comeback, it's hard to tweak it for something inbetween, but right now overall it's somewhere inbetween. Kalista and Ashe are champs that pushes for perma-kiting though.

Ashe is kind of the reason this whole thing started, as giving a ranged champion perma slow imo is a very bad idea. Kiting was always a way to deal with melee champions as they always had to get to you while you pegged them from afar. Now with Kalista I understand what CertainlyT was trying to do but the part of me that went through game design at college screams that he should have known what was going to happen. His intentions were pure as in wanting to teach player to orb walk but he ignored the consequences of his actions. Mobility creep was already a well known problem as well as the problem of melee's vs ranged champions, he outright ignored this and created her anyway. Now the main argument for her is she can't animation cancel, if that's her only weakness besides hard CC which is everyone's weakness, he should have seen it there that it was a bad idea. It not only breaks every rule they set forth for champion design in regards to counterplay but also ignores base common sense as a designer. Because Kalista exists J4 can't be picked in the same game, which goes against their rule of champions should not hard counter others to such an extreme they can't be picked.

> This is the reason why it's hard to make new summoner spells, you can ALWAYS buff them to be as strong as flash, and make flash redundant, but are you sure you want to play a game where barrier/exhaust is the norm?

This is what I spoke about in one of my threads, Flash is countered by Flash and hard CC, Ghost is countered by Flash, Ghost, Exhaust, slows, AND Hard CC. Flash as a summoner spell has nearly zero counterplay by your opponents. Once again going against the base premise of always having good counterplay, What needs to be done is flash needs to be redone mechanically. Either make it like Lissandra's Glacial Path (E) or turn it into a dash as to make it so it is countered by things like Azir's Emperor's Divide (R) and Veigar's Event Horizon (E) that's if you wanted it to be free target. If you wanted to control it even more you could make it like Nautilus's Dredge Line (Q) where if it hits a wall you are pulled to it or if close enough go through it, or even make that its own spell while making Flash like my idea above. 

The problem is Riot themselves See [HERE](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/ta1G4qjz-why-is-flash-allowed-to-be-a-dominant-must-have-spell-but-smite-isnt?comment=0002) where Meddler says that flash is ok because it looks cool not due to any concept of balance (which is the whole reason it needs to be looked at). I have always believed that if you say something you should stick to it, if you can't stick to it explain in explicit detail why you can't. They have given no reason why flash is left how it is other than it looks cool which is not a balance concept. The fact that repeatedly over the last 2 years maybe even longer they have ignored their own CORE design policy is astounding. It's the reason people on the Boards or Reddit don't trust them design wise, they can't follow their own policy. If they followed their own policy then people wouldn't have to question whether they listen at all or why a decision was made, This along with actually explaining why decisions were made would be the first step in patching relations with the playerbase, see lore retcon's not answering why it needed to be done when there were many examples of how it could be done without complete retcon, the Cass rework that ignored feedback and is essentially being done over again. 

I love Riot but that's why it concerns me so when they can't keep their word, it's like a friend you had who you trusted completely but then you see them overtime continuing to lie to you and when you ask them why they blow it off as a joke. You slowly start to lose respect for them as they are continuing to lie and deceive you until you don't recognize who they are anymore. I want to work with them to make things right, I want to work for them to see if any integrity remains, and if not I would leave very quickly as I could not work for a company who doesn't even respect themselves enough to see what they have become.

> The problem is Riot themselves See HERE where Meddler says that flash is ok because it looks cool not due to any concept of balance (which is the whole reason it needs to be looked at).

There you make a major misconception about game design in competitive games. Ultimate goal is not balance, but fun. Entertainment games is made for to entertain, they NEED to be fun, and in this case both as spectator sports and to play. Even if game is unbalanced on some level, even if there is a lack of variety, IF it's more fun that way, it overrides that.

What Riot says makes much more sense if you think from that perspective, instead of thinking about balance and variety as the ultimate goal.

Flash makes better plays, it's simply a too cool ability. It sets up epic plays, and great defenses, partially it's because it's so responsive.

Look from the perspective of a spectator, what would you rather see? Darius that uses ghost, runs up to the ADC, and slam dunks them, or Annie doing a flash tibbers engage on enemy team?

Flash by itself is hard to say it have counterplay or not on, as it's a short dash blink, it's more how it is linked together with other things, and in which context it is used. In some situations there is no available counterplay for that given moment, in the big picture that is overall fine though, if you do it again in a minute you'll kill me as I have no flash then. To example I flash over a wall to escape you when you play Olaf and you have ghost ignite.

Also remember in design you can break ANY rules, as long as you have a good reason. It's all guidelines. And in this case game became more fun, allowed more mastery, and gives the player creativity. You can be creative with flash, you can't be nearly as creative with ghost.

EDIT: I was pretty rough when I said that about Riot I admit it just gets frustrating sometimes, maybe I should have toned it down some.

I originally had a huge 5 paragraph hate rant on design values but I felt as if it was very immature of me so I played a game and cooled off (I need to do this more often, others too) and created this suggestion/retort.

Personally I believe balance should be the most important thing in a game besides being fun to play, as if you don't try to balance the game you are willing to sacrifice one person's fun for another. Flash may create "cool" plays but if you are not willing to force variety then eventually that "cool" factor will completely disappear as it is now the norm. Take the infamous "INSEC" play, after seeing it just about every single competitive game it no longer has that cool factor it once had, instead its just a play that is pulled of by many other people. In most competitive matches you can call out the move about 10-20 seconds ahead of time as it has been seen time and time again. "Oh man he is in a tight spot, oh there is the Ezreal ult and he's over the wall safe and sound." I can't even tell you how many times I have heard something similar to this. If you want to keep the "cool" factor what needs to happen is more than just one mobility spell, to do this you need to change the way summoner spells function. 

Let me explain, the summoner spells would need to be categorized by type, Mobility, Utility, Sustain, and Destructive, (Smite would probably have its own as it is a jungler spell). Mobility would consist of Flash, Ghost, and two other ideas I had as a concept for them. Utility would consist of Teleport, Exhaust, and Clairvoyance. Sustain would be Heal, Clarity, Barrier, and Cleanse. While Destructive would consist of Ignite, and possibly two new spells. My thoughts on this is that flash would be turned into a instant dodge or get over walls spell as its distance would be reduced for just that purpose. Each player can chose up to one from any one category i.e. a person can't take Heal and Barrier as they are both sustain spells but they may take Flash and Heal. > "What are people most interested or vocal about?"
> "Aside from the concrete data - do people feel that this character is OP or UP?"
> "What elements of a larger patch or feature are people most drawn to or that is most contentious"
> 
> *Easy Wins* - These are specific changes that are really easy to do, something I could tackle over lunch without sacrificing my current projects. Often these are champion QoL fixes or bug/feel investigations.
> Examples include
> Switching a skill to a new targeting indicator
> Investigating reports of a characters AA feeling weird
> Updates to a champions recommended items
> Minor particle updates I can fix with my bad art skills (ex- displaying all 3 cards during Twisted Fates Pick a Card for colorblind people)
> 
> *Discovering Important or unImportant elements *- When I was working on the Udyr and Trundle updates a long time ago reading community feedback on those champions in general was super useful in evaluating what elements of the character people seemed most attached with on each character and what they simply didn't care about. I found out pretty quickly, and not super surprisingly, that people didn't really care about the flat bonus AP on phoenix stance and it was viewed as practically worthless. Stripping this bonus damage out allowed me to put the phoenix fire breath cone on the very first punch upon switching stances for nearly identical total damage but made him more satisfying and allowed him more interesting positional play and let him rotate stances faster.
>

A specific example here would be the Critical Strike or Grievous Wounds discussions that pop up from time to time.
